        <tei-body data-origname="body">
            <tei-div data-origname="div">
               <tei-pb n="3" facs="v1n1p3" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-seg data-origname="seg">REVUE</tei-seg><tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>DES <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/><tei-seg data-origname="seg">COLONIES</tei-seg></tei-head>
                <tei-div xml:id="prospectus" id="prospectus" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
                    <tei-head rend="bold" data-origname="head" data-origatts="rend">Prospectus.</tei-head>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p"> As of now, the colonies, generally speaking, only know of the great
                        principles of philanthropy in theory; of freedom in action, nothing at all. </tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p"> The suffering and oppressed classes appeal and fight relentlessly, always in
                        vain. To stimulate the feeble good will to which our rulers limit
                        themselves, it is necessary to compile the just complaints that arise from
                        all sides. These claims, these grievances, to be successful, must receive
                        the greatest publicity: this is the object of our <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title ref="#RdC" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref">Revue</tei-title></tei-bibl>
                    </tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p"> The debate floor <tei-emph data-origname="emph">today</tei-emph> is no longer enough; petitions are
                        adjourned by the calculated negligence of rapporteurs or pushed back by the 
                        insolent agendas of the day. On the other hand, colonial authorities, always
                        disposed in favor of the privileged, cleverly evade the ministers' prescriptions. Against this hitherto successful tactic
                        of the partisans of aristocracy and privilege, it is necessary to finally
                        engage the power of public opinion, enlightened by a discussion always wise,
                        always true, but energetic and never timid, of the causes, whatever they may
                        be, which hinder the desirable fusion of the diverse populations of the
                            colonies.<tei-ptr target="#n4F2A" n="2" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/>
                    </tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p"> For this purpose, a specialized journal is founded under the title of <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title ref="#RdC" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref"> Revue des Colonies</tei-title></tei-bibl>,
                        with <tei-persName ref="#CB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. Bissette</tei-persName> as director. </tei-p>
                    <tei-pb n="4" facs="v1n1p4" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p"> This journal is not only dedicated to all that concerns the colonies,
                        considered as a source of news and interesting facts apt to occupy the
                        leisure of the reader, but it devotes itself entirely to the political,
                        intellectual, moral and industrial interests of colonists of either
                            color.<tei-ptr target="#n6CEA" n="3" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/>
                    </tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p"> Nothing that concerns the French colonies in particular will be omitted from
                        this monthly publication. The government, the administration, and the justice
                        system will be examined here with respect to both their actions and their
                        persons; for it is the latter that too often determines the spirit and
                        the manner in which populations are either oppressed or well looked
                        after.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p"> The civil, political, and social rights of the two free classes, which,
                        having been hitherto divided, ought to be united, will here be advanced and
                        supported with indefatigable zeal. </tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p"> The great question of the abolition of slavery, the cornerstone of liberty,
                        will here be treated with the most conscientious care and the most ardent
                        love of equality and of the general good.<tei-ptr target="#n79DB" n="4" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/>
                    </tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">Arbitrariness and partiality will here be brought to face the court of public
                        opinion with no distinction between persons. The weak will find here support
                        and protection, the oppressor, punishment, the official, warranted blame for
                        his illegal acts, but respect for his person. </tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p"> The <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title> will also concern itself with all the
                        changes made or projected in the legislation that governs foreign colonies
                        and inevitably affects our own in a powerful way.<tei-ptr target="#n5699" n="5" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/>
                    </tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p"> National interests, in relation to the possession of
                            <tei-placeName ref="#Alg" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Algiers</tei-placeName>, will find in the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des
                            Colonies</tei-title> a devoted and independent outlet.<tei-ptr target="#n6ED7" n="6" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/>
                    </tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p"> Numerous and knowledgeable correspondents ensure that readers find as much
                        variety as edification in the articles of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des
                            Colonies.</tei-title>
                    </tei-p>
                </tei-div>
                <tei-pb data-origname="pb" data-empty=""/>
                <tei-div xml:id="declaration" id="declaration" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
                  <tei-pb n="5" facs="v1n1p5" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                    <tei-head data-origname="head">DECLARATION OF PRINCIPLES.</tei-head>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p"> The <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title> believes it must, above all, indicate
                        by what principles it will offer judgment upon men and things.<tei-ptr target="#n3E34" n="7" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/> In its estimation, '89, in the immortal Declaration
                        of Rights voted by the <tei-orgName ref="#AN" data-origname="orgName" data-origatts="ref">National Assembly</tei-orgName>, laid
                        the future foundations of all truly democratic institutions; this is why we
                        inscribe this <tei-title data-origname="title">Declaration</tei-title> at the beginning of this
                        compendium: these are the tables of our law. </tei-p>
                    <tei-epigraph data-origname="epigraph">
                        <tei-cit data-origname="cit">
                            <tei-quote data-origname="quote">The rights of men had been misunderstood, insulted for centuries;
                                they have been restored for all mankind by this
                                    <tei-title data-origname="title">Declaration</tei-title>, which will forever remain a rallying
                                cry against oppressors, and a law for legislators themselves. </tei-quote>
                            <tei-bibl type="legal" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type">(Address of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">National Assembly</tei-orgName>
                                to the French People, 11 February 1790.)</tei-bibl>
                        </tei-cit>
                    </tei-epigraph>
                </tei-div>
                <tei-div data-origname="div">
                    <tei-head rend="bold" data-origname="head" data-origatts="rend">Excerpt</tei-head>
                    <tei-head data-origname="head">FROM THE MINUTES OF THE <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">NATIONAL ASSEMBLY</tei-orgName> OF AUGUST 20,
                        21, 22, 23, 24, 26 AND OCTOBER 1st, 1789.</tei-head>
                    <tei-floatingText data-origname="floatingText">
                        <tei-body data-origname="body">
                            <tei-div data-origname="div">
                                <tei-head data-origname="head">DECLARATION OF THE RIGHTS OF MAN IN SOCIETY.<tei-ptr target="#n7767" n="8" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/></tei-head>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p">The representatives of the French People, formed into a National
                                    Assembly, considering ignorance, forgetfulness or contempt of
                                    the rights of man to be the only causes of public misfortunes
                                    and the corruption of Governments, have resolved to set forth,
                                    in a solemn Declaration, the natural, unalienable and sacred
                                    rights of man, to the end that this Declaration, constantly
                                    present to all members of the body politic, may remind them
                                    unceasingly of their rights and their duties; to the end that
                                    the acts of the legislative power and those of the executive
                                    power, since they may be continually compared with the aim of
                                    every political institution, may thereby be the more respected;
                                    to the end that the demands of the citizens, founded henceforth
                                    on simple and incontestable principles, may always be directed
                                    toward the maintenance of the Constitution and the happiness of
                                    all. </tei-p>
                                <tei-pb n="6" facs="v1n1p6" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p"> In consequence whereof, the National Assembly recognizes and
                                    declares, in the presence and under the auspices of the Supreme
                                    Being, the following Rights of Man and of the Citizen. </tei-p>
                                <tei-p xml:id="art1" id="art1" data-origname="p" data-origatts="xml:id">Article 1.-Men are born and remain free and equal in rights.
                                    Social distinctions may be based only on considerations of the
                                    common good.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p">2.- The aim of every political association is the preservation of
                                    the natural and imprescriptible rights of man. These rights are
                                    Liberty, Property, Safety and Resistance to Oppression.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p xml:id="art3" id="art3" data-origname="p" data-origatts="xml:id">3.-The source of all sovereignty lies essentially in the Nation.
                                    No corporate body, no individual may exercise any authority that
                                    does not expressly emanate from it.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p">4.- Liberty consists in being able to do anything that does not
                                    harm others: thus, the exercise of the natural rights of every
                                    man has no bounds other than those that ensure to the other
                                    members of society the enjoyment of these same rights. These
                                    bounds may be determined only by Law.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-gap reason="accidental" unit="number" extent="1" data-origname="gap" data-origatts="extent unit reason" data-empty=""/><tei-supplied data-origname="supplied">5.-</tei-supplied> The Law has the right to forbid
                                    only those actions that are injurious to society. Nothing that
                                    is not forbidden by Law may be hindered, and no one may be
                                    compelled to do what the Law does not ordain.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-choice data-origname="choice">
                                        <tei-sic data-origname="sic">5.-</tei-sic>
                                        <tei-corr data-origname="corr">6.-</tei-corr>
                                    </tei-choice>The Law is the expression of the general will. All
                                    citizens have the right to take part, personally or through
                                    their representatives, in its making. It must be the same for
                                    all, whether it protects or punishes. All citizens, being equal
                                    in its eyes, shall be equally eligible to all high offices,
                                    public positions and employments, according to their ability,
                                    and without other distinction than that of their virtues and
                                    talents.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p">7.- No man may be accused, arrested or detained except in the
                                    cases determined by the Law, and following the procedure that it
                                    has prescribed. Those who solicit, expedite, carry out, or cause
                                    to be carried out arbitrary orders must be punished; but any
                                    citizen summoned or apprehended by virtue of the Law, must give
                                    instant obedience; resistance makes him guilty.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p"> 8.- The Law must prescribe only the punishments that are
                                    strictly and evidently necessary; and no one may be punished
                                    except by virtue of a Law drawn up and promulgated before the
                                    offense is committed, and legally applied.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p">9.- As every man is presumed innocent until he has <tei-pb n="7" facs="v1n1p7" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                                    been declared guilty, if it should be considered necessary to
                                    arrest him, any undue harshness that is not required to secure
                                    his person must be severely curbed by Law.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p">10. - No one may be disturbed on account of his opinions, even
                                    religious ones, as long as the manifestation of such opinions
                                    does not interfere with the established Law and Order.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p">11.- The free communication of ideas and of opinions is one of
                                    the most precious rights of man. Any citizen may therefore
                                    speak, write and publish freely, except what is tantamount to
                                    the abuse of this liberty in the cases determined by Law.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p">12.- To guarantee the Rights of Man and of the Citizen a public
                                    force is necessary; this force is therefore established for the
                                    benefit of all, and not for the particular use of those to whom
                                    it is entrusted.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p">13. For the maintenance of the public force, and for
                                    administrative expenses, a general tax is indispensable; it must
                                    be equally distributed among all citizens, in proportion to
                                    their ability to pay.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p">14. All citizens have the right to ascertain, by themselves, or
                                    through their representatives, the need for a public tax, to
                                    consent to it freely, to watch over its use, and to determine
                                    its proportion, basis, collection and duration.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p">15. Society has the right to ask a public official for an
                                    accounting of his administration.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p data-origname="p">16. Any society in which no provision is made for guaranteeing
                                    rights or for the separation of powers, has no Constitution.</tei-p>
                                <tei-p xml:id="art17" id="art17" data-origname="p" data-origatts="xml:id">17.- Since the right to Property is inviolable and sacred, no one
                                    may be deprived thereof, unless public necessity, legally
                                    ascertained, obviously requires it, and just and prior indemnity
                                    has been paid.</tei-p>
                                <tei-closer data-origname="closer"> Excerpt from the minutes of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">National
                                        Assembly</tei-orgName>, October 1, 1789. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Collated true to
                                    the original. <tei-signed data-origname="signed">Signed MOUNIER, president; Viscount DE
                                        MIRABEAU, DEMEUNIER, BUREAU DE Pusy, Bishop DE NANCY,
                                        FAYDEL, Abbot of EYMAR, secretaries. </tei-signed>
                                </tei-closer>
                            </tei-div>
                        </tei-body>
                    </tei-floatingText>
                    <tei-pb n="8" facs="v1n1p8" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">All of the principles of '89 are in this declaration; and, whatever one does,
                        there is in these principles, which the French revolution, by its republican
                        and imperial armies, has sown acrossed the land of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Europe</tei-placeName>, and by its books everywhere in the universe, a
                        power which cannot be suppressed. </tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">Certainly, if a man should be reminded of anything, it is his rights, which
                        aristocracies may well succeed in making obsolete here and there, but to
                        which the future belongs.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">We ask that we compare the present state of our legislation with this page of
                        justice and liberty, that we examine whether the laws that are made for us
                        are in conformity with the principles of this declaration, which must be
                        forever, according to the fine expression of the <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">National
                            Assembly</tei-orgName>, <tei-emph data-origname="emph">the law of the legislators
                        themselves</tei-emph>. And if this examination clearly shows that the government,
                        whatever it may be, is not founded on this one equitable basis — the
                        enforcement of the rights of all — those who, like us and with the
                            <tei-orgName data-origname="orgName">National Assembly</tei-orgName>, will be convinced that
                            <tei-emph data-origname="emph">ignorance, forgetfulness or contempt for the rights of man are the
                            only causes of public misfortunes and the corruption of
                            governments</tei-emph>, will triumphantly conclude that all the evil of the
                        present situation, in the colonies as everywhere, is absolutely a result of
                        this ignorance, of this forgetfulness or of this contempt, we cannot
                        precisely say which, as much on the part of the rulers as on that of the
                        governed.</tei-p>
                    <tei-closer data-origname="closer">
                        <tei-emph data-origname="emph">The director</tei-emph>, <tei-signed data-origname="signed"><tei-persName ref="#CB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">BISSETTE</tei-persName>.</tei-signed>
                    </tei-closer>
                </tei-div>
                <tei-div xml:id="regime" id="regime" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
                    <tei-head data-origname="head">A LOOK AT THE COLONIAL REGIME AND ITS EFFECTS.</tei-head>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">The deplorable events of Grand'Anse, <tei-ptr target="#n590A" n="9" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/>
                        <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName> have echoed through every
                        newspaper. Some, inspired by the authorities, in whose eyes all that is
                        emancipation becomes an object of terror, have presented this affair in an
                        unfavorable light to those who have limited themselves to passive
                            resistance.<tei-ptr target="#n684A" n="10" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/> Others, more benevolent, and above
                        all, more impartial, were careful not to pass premature judgment on a matter
                        of this nature: they knew that passion exaggerates both evil and good, and
                        that one should not <tei-pb n="9" facs="v1n1p9" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>rush to adopt the words of a powerful and
                        often unjust party. </tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">We too will attend to this matter, but by prefacing it with all the
                        considerations necessary to draw the correct conclusions.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">These facts, which seem to us hardly believable, are repeated every day with
                        impunity in our colonies. And how could it not be so, when the men charged
                        with maintaining the laws are those most interested in violating them!
                        Arbitrariness is therefore only the sad corollary of a state of affairs
                        whose origins date back to a time of conquest, plunder and brutal violence.
                        We know that this arbitrariness exists; philosophy has decried it; power
                        itself seems to reject a shameful solidarity, and yet nothing real has been
                        done to put an end to it. Everything has been deceit and lies, from the
                        illusory measures against the slave trade, to the laws which seem to grant
                        men of color the rights of citizens, and a justice which one could not
                        truthfully represent scales in the hand.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">These causes, which, deriving from the overall regime of the colonies, would seem foreign to the events of Grand'Anse, to which we will attend more particularly, 
                    <tei-ptr target="#n65C6" n="11" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/> are nevertheless attached to them by a multitude of threads:
                        for nothing in the fate of peoples, as in that of men, is isolated, and the
                        actual effects are often produced by causes lost to the depths of time.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">The colonies too, despite their distance from the motherland, felt the
                        effects of the great political commotion which regenerated <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">France</tei-placeName>. A long subjugation, largely exploited by
                        the aristocracy, had not been able to paralyze hearts so much that they did
                        not feel warmed by the rays of the sun of freedom. Men of color especially,
                        more advantaged than the unfortunate slaves, turned their eyes towards
                        France with love and confidence; they felt that each link which fell from
                        the chains of old Europe was for them a pledge of emancipation. The
                        emblazoned nobility, elevated to the rank of people, offered an edifying
                        lesson to the nobility of the skin,<tei-ptr target="#n2BFD" n="12" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/> which did not
                        even possess the prestige of the former's personal accomplishments. The
                        destruction of one was the sure guarantee of the destruction of the other.
                        Was not the emancipation of the people, who had long suffered the bondage <tei-pb n="10" facs="v1n1p10" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>of the field, also a sign of freedom for the slaves? There was
                        therefore in the colonies what is still there today, an absurd aristocracy
                        clinging to its privileges and willing to go to any length to preserve them,
                        and on the other hand a population full of verve, of energy, beginning to
                        understand its rights and its dignity. </tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">Such, then, was the position of the colonies when the July revolution,<tei-ptr target="#n9F29" n="13" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/> so rich in prospects, made conceivable for a moment
                        the awakening of France. The new government, carried along, no doubt in
                        spite of itself, by the force of circumstance, not daring to lift the veil
                        which hid its ulterior motives, finally bowing before public opinion which
                        had just had its impact felt, erased the word <tei-emph data-origname="emph">regulations</tei-emph> from
                        the article of the charter concerning the colonies. It declared that the
                        colonies would be governed by special <tei-emph data-origname="emph">laws</tei-emph><tei-ptr target="#n3257" n="14" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/>. This tacit recognition of abuses of all kinds, originating in the
                        corrupted system of ordinences, stoked the hopes of those who could still
                        put some faith in ministers' promises. It was because they did not believe
                        that a government born of democracy could so quickly forget its origin; they
                        did not comprehend that the preservation of titles of nobility, of a
                        so-called upper chamber, and above all of an exaggerated civil list were
                        milestones laid down by the nascent power to constitute itself on bases
                        similar to that which the popular arm had just crushed. Did not the
                        preservation of the titled nobility in the motherland,<tei-ptr target="#n917D" n="15" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/> and the addition that was made to it of a Turcarets aristrocracy,<tei-ptr target="#n9C9A" n="16" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/> clearly impart to the colonies that, except for a few
                        slight adjustments, their aristocracy of skin would be preserved along with
                        most of its privileges.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">Indeed these fine particular <tei-emph data-origname="emph">laws</tei-emph> were rendered so illusory as
                        to match the ordinances' arbitrariness,<tei-ptr target="#n332A" n="17" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/> differing from
                        them only by the hypocrisy of the name. For example, is not the electoral
                        law, establishing the political rights of whites and of men of color, a work
                        of perfidious deception? On the <tei-placeName ref="#BrB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">isle of
                            Bourbon</tei-placeName> and of <tei-placeName ref="#Cay" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Cayenne</tei-placeName>,
                        where the whites are in overwhelming majority, the electoral qualification
                        and eligibility are fixed at a lower rate, for there is no fear of
                        competition; but in the colonies of <tei-placeName ref="#GP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Guadeloupe
                        </tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>, where the
                        population of color, quite numerous, is of <tei-pb n="11" facs="v1n1p11" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>average wealth, the
                        tax is preemptively raised to an unattainable level. Is there anything more
                        perfidious, I would even say more odiously ironic, than to thus concede the
                        right while prohibiting the means. Would it not have been truer to declare
                        outright that only whites could vote?<tei-ptr target="#n0490" n="18" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/></tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">It became difficult, in the presence of this law of political organization,
                        creating or rather sanctioning a privilege, to allow for the action of the
                        popular will. The national guard, that
                        admirable institution of the métropole,<tei-ptr target="#n5F16" n="19" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/> had a pale
                        imitation in the colonies, where both the name and the democratic element of
                        election were carefully banished.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">If France has a national guard, the colonies have a militia whose officers,
                        appointed by the governor, are generally taken from the white population and
                        from among a few men of color. These, to keep a rank obtained by favor,
                        devote themselves unquestioningly to the governor and become his
                        accomplices. We hasten to say that, among those promoted, we count friends
                        who have not wavered in their political opinions, but not all of them are
                        so. When power makes itself odious by its partiality, it always corrupts the
                        men who make themselves its supporters. What bonds can indeed unite men who
                        find themselves in a position so false as the colonial militia and its
                        leaders? Trust? It does not exist. Fraternity? it would be vain to search
                        for it there. So there remains only force, and it is indeed felt
                        everyday.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">In the judicial system, abuses abound, and they are always to the advantage
                        of the aristocratic class. The royal courts and the magistrates' courts are
                        constituted in such a way as to let the whites become judges and parties in
                        their own cause. Finally, despite the very text of the charter, provost
                        courts can still bloody the soil of the colonies by legally assassinating
                        the innocent people they want to get rid of.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">Well! in the presence of this boundless arbitrariness, leaning on their
                        numerous privileges, the whites groan and complain that the government has
                        dared to touch the holy ark of their power, by diminishing some of their
                        privileges. Political rights, they possess them all; the judicial power is
                        in their hands; law enforcement, they<tei-pb n="12" facs="v1n1p12" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> direct and command it; but
                        it is not enough to suit their wounded pride. A principle, admittedly
                        without application, has been issued; the word equality was spoken, was it
                        not enough to offend those selfish and hard hearts for whom every
                        independent man who is not part of their league is but a worthless
                        rebellious slave?<tei-ptr target="#n3701" n="20" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/> Men of color, on the contrary,
                        confident in the government's feeble pledges of good will, waited patiently
                        for better days perfecting their political education so as to wield the
                        influence that they are entitled to in their country by their rights and
                        numbers. And what do they really want that is not wise and reasonable?
                        Placed in their land in the same position as the third estate in France
                        before the revolution, they then ask what this order commanded: liberty and
                        equality. But they are dealing with privileged people who are even more
                        tenacious than the nobility and clergy of France. These at least did not
                        have the impudence to deny the title of men to their adversaries.<tei-ptr target="#n8508" n="21" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/>
                    </tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">By what means, then, could the privileged recover the integrity of their
                        privileges? To ask the government for them was impossible, they would have
                        been told to bide their time; that the compromise was only a matter of
                        painful necessity; that, moreover, the liberties granted to the mulattoes
                        were purely illusory, being limited in reality to a few slight concessions
                        of sociability.<tei-ptr target="#n6759" n="22" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/> And furthermore these same concessions
                        often bend according to the whims of the aristocracy. These answers, which
                        would satisfy less impatient, and above all less prideful men, would have
                        deeply wounded those imperious masters whose despotism is exercised without
                        control over unfortunate slaves. It was therefore necessary to employ all
                        means, even calumny, to subjugate the class of color and crush it.<tei-ptr target="#n7A20" n="23" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/> It had to be represented as factious, turbulent,
                        having sworn to destroy the whites and stopping at nothing, not murder, not
                        arson, to accomplish this. It is so easy to slander men who are not allowed
                        to defend themselves! To find guilty the enemy that one judges oneself! And
                        then the colonies also count among their ranks men who know how to create
                        conspiracies, foment them, cause them to arise at the right time, in order
                        to take advantage of them in their own interest. And what does it really
                        matter that the worthless blood of a few negroes comes to redden the ground!
                        What does it matter if a mulatto's head rolls on<tei-pb n="13" facs="v1n1p13" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> the scaffold!
                        Mere trifles, when you consider the glorious result expected of it; that is,
                        the bondage of the many for the benefit of the few. Besides, the métropole
                        offers a few examples which would seem to authorize the colonies in this
                        Machiavellianism.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">And so we have seen the birth of these imaginary plots, these conflagrations
                        whose frequency during certain periods bespeaks frightful mysteries.
                        Innocents have been accused, thrown into dungeons, tortured, shot without
                        pity when they allowed themselves a few complaints. Neither sex nor age
                        could soften these ferocious men who subject their slaves to the most
                        sophisticated cruelties, and their gold, thrown at the heads of the
                        proconsuls of the great nation, hides large stains of blood from their
                        eyes.</tei-p>
                    <tei-p data-origname="p">Ah! if some day an eloquent pen tearing the funereal veil which covers our
                        colonies, would retrace the history of domination of the possessors of
                        men; if it evoked from the depths of their tombs the sad victims who are
                        heaped there every day, never would a country defiled by tyranny offer such
                        horrible pages.<tei-ptr target="#n4C92" n="24" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/> All that we read of the Mésences, the
                        Caligulas, the Louis XIs,<tei-ptr target="#n5DA0" n="25" data-origname="ptr" data-origatts="n target" data-empty=""/> all that our hearts refuse
                        to believe as too degrading for humanity, finds itself surpassed in the
                        nineteenth century by overseas Frenchmen. But these horrible scenes of
                        despotism have no place here, elsewhere we will reveal them by throwing the
                        names of their infamous authors among the ignominies of history. </tei-p>
                </tei-div>
            </tei-div>
        </tei-body>

  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n13FA" id="n13FA" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">La <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies </tei-title>souscrit pleinement à la mode, importée d’Angleterre dans les années 1800, des périodiques non-quotidiens destinés essentiellement à une élite lettrée. Comme l’indique la désignation « recueil » dans le sous-titre, il s’agit d’une compilation de textes divers sélectionnés par le directeur comme représentatifs de l’actualité politique, administrative, juridique, et culturelle du monde colonial. La forme éditoriale de la revue (de son étymologie anglaise, <tei-title data-origname="title">review</tei-title>, c’est-à-dire, bilan ou récapitulatif) vise en effet, autant par sa structure que par sa périodicité, à faire la synthèse des événements marquants des semaines écoulées. </tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">La <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>s’attache également à sensibiliser le lecteur métropolitain aux conditions de vie des populations de couleur, libres ou esclavisées, des territoires coloniaux ainsi qu’à promouvoir l’apport culturel, littéraire et artistique d’auteurs et personnalités de couleur avec des rubriques spécialisées, d’où l’insistence du sous-titre sur les « moeurs » et l’« instruction ».</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Comme toutes les publications de son genre, la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>répond plus du livre que du journal par son format (grand in-octavo), sa mise en page traditionnelle et la taille, relativement conséquente, de ses livraisons (de 40 à 48 pages). Celles-ci sont d’ailleurs destinées à être reliées en fin d’année afin d’être recueillies, comme des livres, dans les bibliothèques, ainsi qu’en atteste la numérotation continue des pages, introduite dès le second volume. Régulier au cours des deux premières années, le tirage de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>sera sujet, par la suite, à des interruptions ponctuelles jusqu’à l’arrêt définitif de sa publication en juin 1842. </tei-p>

    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">The form of the “review,” a non-daily periodical offering a survey of current events, commentary, and reprinted material, originates in Romantic-era English print culture.  As indicated by the designation “compendium” in the subtitle, the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title> is a compilation of various texts selected by the editors as representative of the political, administrative, legal and cultural news of the colonial world. In choosing the form of the “review” (in the sense of survey or evaluation), the journal indicates its aim to summarize the significant occurrences of the previous weeks.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Like most publications of its kind, the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, printed in-octavo, with single column pages, in relatively long issues (40 to 50 pages), more closely resembles a book than a newspaper. Issues are designed to be bound at the end of each year in order to be collected as volumes, as evidenced by the continuous numbering of the pages between issues, beginning in the second year of the journal's print run. </tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Though making the metropolitan French reader aware of the hardships experienced by people of color, free or enslaved, was the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title>'s main objective, it also aimed to promote the literary, artistic, and cultural contributions of contemporaneous writers and historical figures of color. It did so through regular features and reprints, hence the insistence, in the subtitle, on “customs” and “instruction.”</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Printed regularly over the first two years, the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> was, thereafter, subject to occasional interruptions until its final issue in June 1842.</tei-p>

  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n4F2A" id="n4F2A" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette notion de « fusion » revient souvent dans la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, qui lui consacre, notamment, un article intitulé « De la fusion des deux races aux colonies et des causes qui la retardent » (décembre 1834, p. 1-7). Proposée comme moyen d’abolir la hiérarchie raciale des colonies par le métissage, elle peut paraître utopique, voire naïve. Comme l’a signalé Marlene Daut, elle demeure néanmoins ancrée, pour Bissette et ses associés, dans une conscience nécessaire des rapports de force profondément inégalitaires que le métissage impliquait, en pratique, dans le contexte colonial. </tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Bongie, Chris. <tei-title data-origname="title">Islands and Exiles: The Creole Identities of Post/colonial Literature</tei-title>, Stanford, Californie : Stanford University Press, 1998, p. 274-275.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Daut, Marlene L. <tei-title data-origname="title">Tropics of Haiti</tei-title>, Liverpool : Liverpool University Press, 2015, p. 345‑372.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Manchuelle, François. « Le rôle des Antillais dans l’apparition du nationalisme culturel en Afrique noire francophone », <tei-title data-origname="title">Cahiers d'Études Africaines</tei-title> 32, no. 127, 1992, p. 375‑408.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This notion of “fusion” appears frequently in the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, notably in article in the December 1834 issue entitled “Of the fusion of the two races in the colonies and the causes that delay it” (“De la fusion des deux races aux colonies et des causes qui la retardent,” <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title>, December 1834, 1-7). As Marlene Daut has noted, for the "society of men of color" at the helm of the journal, this notion of fusion remains inextricable from the history of sexual violence that racial mixing implied, in practice, in the colonial context.</tei-p>

  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n6CEA" id="n6CEA" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette phrase apporte un éclairage essentiel sur la politique éditoriale de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>à ses débuts. Si l’objectif est de combattre le système esclavagiste en commençant, en premier lieu, par le démantèlement de l’ordre ségregationniste des colonies par la revendication des droits civiques des personnes de couleur libres, la voie choisie par Bissette et ses associés dans cette première livraison est, que ce soit pour des raisons idéologiques sincères ou pour des raisons stratégiques, celle de la conciliation et de l’assimilationnisme social. Il n’y est, par ailleurs, pas question d’envisager une quelconque indépendance des Antilles, et ce particulièrement dans une décennie qui voit la France étendre son empire à l’Algérie après avoir perdu plusieurs territoires de son premier empire colonial. La perspective que Bissette affiche par le biais de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> reste celle d’un Français qui croit à la vitalité de l’Empire et n’envisage pas d’alternative au système colonial. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This claim is indicative of the editorial politics of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> in its early days. Though the ultimate goal remains the abolition of slavery and the dismantlement of the colonies' segregationist order, Bissette and his associates adopt an overhwelmingly assimilationist and conciliatory position with regard to metropolitan France. This may be a pragmatic decision, given the slim possibility of independence for the Caribbean colonies, in the decade that saw France extend its empire to Algeria. The position Bissette adopts throughout the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>’s print run is, thus, ostensibly that of a colonial and imperial subject who does not see the need to pursue any alternative forms of governance.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n79DB" id="n79DB" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Si Bissette et ses associés Fabien et Richard avaient rédigé, au cours des deux années précédentes, plusieurs textes et pétitions à visée explicitement émancipatrice, cette déclaration suggère une approche plus conciliante, sans doute par souci d’attirer un nombre important d’abonnés, mais aussi, potentiellement, par crainte de censure officielle ou de répercussions juridiques. Un an plus tard, la première livraison du second volume tient un discours bien plus explicitement et résolument abolitionniste. </tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-ref target="RdCv2n1-fr" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Juillet 1835</tei-ref></tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Unlike the more explicitly emancipatory tracts that Bissette and his associates Fabien and Richard had drafted over the previous two years, this declaration suggests a more conciliatory approach, likely out of concern for attracting and maintaining subscribers, but also, potentially, for fear of official censorship or legal repercussions. A year later, the first issue of the second volume features markedly more radical abolitionist arguments.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-ref target="RdCv2n1-en" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">July 1835</tei-ref></tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n6ED7" id="n6ED7" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Cet oxymore souligne l’attitude paradoxale de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> et de son rédacteur quant au projet colonial. Comme beaucoup de ses contemporains, le libéralisme de Bissette, même lorsqu’il est au plus explicite dans ses engagements antiesclavagistes et antiségrégationnistes, n’est jamais explicitement décolonial. Toutefois, l’apparente adhésion, voire la « dévotion » de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> au modèle colonial, mérite d’être nuancée, notamment par les propos tenus dès l’année suivante, dans <tei-ref target="RdCv2n1-fr#abolition" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">l’article sur le projet de loi pour l’abolition immédiate</tei-ref>. La France y est invoquée, de manière ouvertement pragmatique, au titre d’arbitre nécessaire à la transition de « l’ancien au nouvel état produit par l’abolition de l’esclavage », dans une allusion claire à l’embargo économique et diplomatique d’Haïti aux lendemains de son idépendance. (juillet 1835, p. 10)</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This oxymoron underlines the paradoxical attitude  the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> adopts regarding France's imperial and colonial project. Bissette's liberalism does not explicitly extend from anti-slavery to anti-colonialism. However, the apparent adhesion, even “devotion,” of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> to the French empire, is not without complication, particularly in its discussion of the <tei-ref target="RdCv2n1-en#abolition" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">bill for immediate abolition published the following year</tei-ref>. France is invoked there, in the spirit of pragmatism, as the necessary arbiter for the transition from “the old to the new state produced by the abolition of slavery,” in a clear allusion to the economic and diplomatic embargo of Haiti in the aftermath of its independence. (July 1835, 10)</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n65C6" id="n65C6" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Une série d’articles intitulés « Affaire de la Grand’Anse » paraît dans les trois premières livraisons de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, revenant sur les particularités de l’affaire et la procédure judiciaire qui s'en est suivie tout au long de la première année.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">A series of articles entitled “Affaire de la Grand’Anse” appeared in the first three issues of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, detailing the specifics of the case and the legal proceedings that followed.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n2BFD" id="n2BFD" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette expression vise à mettre en équivalence le statut privilégié des colons blancs avec celui qui est réservé à la noblesse, et par extension à opérer un parallèle entre la hiérarchie raciale de la société coloniale et celle de l’Ancien Régime. De fait, l’ensemble des diverses mesures discriminatoires mises en place par les ordonnances coloniales à l’encontre de la population de couleur libre est souvent désigné par l’expression « préjugé de couleur », ce qui en fait le pendant colonial du préjugé de noblesse de la France d’Ancien Régime. </tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Régent, Frédéric. « Préjugé de couleur, esclavage et citoyennetés dans les colonies françaises (1789-1848) », <tei-title data-origname="title">La Révolution française</tei-title>. 17 novembre 2015 n<tei-hi rend="superscript" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">o</tei-hi> 9.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This original expression analogizes the privileged status of white settlers in the colonies to that of Old Regime nobility. In so doing, it echoes the phrase “prejudice of color,” which was used to refer collectively to the various discriminatory measures put in place by colonial ordinances against the free population of color.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Régent, Frédéric. “Préjugé de couleur, esclavage et citoyennetés dans les colonies françaises (1789-1848),”  <tei-title data-origname="title">La Révolution française</tei-title> 9 (2015). 1-37.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n7A20" id="n7A20" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Référence transparente aux victimes de l’<tei-title data-origname="title">affaire Bissette</tei-title>, dont Bissette et Fabien, mais également à celles de l’<tei-title data-origname="title">affaire de la Grand’Anse.</tei-title></tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This is a transparent allusion to the victims of the <tei-title data-origname="title">affaire Bissette</tei-title>, including the founders of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, as well as those of the <tei-title data-origname="title">affaire de la Grand’Anse</tei-title>.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n4C92" id="n4C92" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Déclaration aussi surprenante qu’évocatrice des engagements réels de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue.</tei-title></tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This passage of elevated rhetoric effectively constitutes a mission statement for the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue.</tei-title></tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n5699" id="n5699" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette référence claire à l’abolition de l’esclavage britannique décrétée en août 1833, et devant entrer en vigueur en août 1834, soit quelques semaines après la première livraison de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, permet d’identifier l’'un des moteurs politiques de la fondation du périodique.  La référence comprend également une allusion implicite aux insurrections antiesclavagistes de l’ancienne colonie française de Saint-Domingue qui ont précipité la première abolition française de l’esclavage en 1794. À l’époque de la première livraison de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, l’émancipation et l’éventuelle indépendance d’Haïti constituent une menace pour les sociétés coloniales et esclavagistes, et exercent de ce fait une influence importante sur l’administration des territoires coloniaux. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This reference to the British Abolition Act, passed in August 1833, which would take effect only a few weeks after the first issue of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, in August 1834, is indicative of its impetus and political ambitions. The phrasing also appears to make implicit reference to the slave insurrections in the former colony of Saint-Domingue that ultimately brought about the first French abolition in 1794. At the time of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>’s publication, the emancipation and ultimate independence of Haiti were perceived as persistent threats to the colonial system, with lasting effects on French international and colonial policy.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n7767" id="n7767" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Bissette choisit de réimprimer les procès-verbaux, un tirage séparé plus rare, et moins référencé de la Déclaration, qui contenait également les articles de la première Constitution française. Ce document était initialement destiné au cercle restreint de ceux qui ont participé à sa création, avec des copies limitées à ces personnes. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Bissette chooses to reprint the minutes (“procès-verbaux”) of the meetings of the National Constituent Assembly during which the Declaration was discussed and adopted. This rarer, less referenced separate edition of the Declaration, also contained the articles of the first French Constitution. Copies of this document were originally limited to those who participated in its creation.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n590A" id="n590A" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette <tei-title data-origname="title">affaire</tei-title>, qui a bénéficié d’une couverture médiatique importante dans la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> et ailleurs, a pour origine une altercation, en août 1833, entre un planteur blanc et un homme de couleur libre qui aboutit à  une mobilisation fermement réprimée. Sur plus d’une centaine d’accusés, la majorité reçoit de sévères condamnations —  travaux forcés, déportations, exécutions — à l’issue d’un procès expéditif mené par la justice locale. L’article « Coup d’œil sur le régime colonial et ses effets » est d’ailleurs suivi d’un article entièrement consacré à l’« Insurrection de la Grand’Anse » énumérant les 117 accusés.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Schloss, Rebecca Hartkopf. <tei-title data-origname="title">Sweet Liberty : The Final Days of Slavery in Martinique</tei-title> Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2011. p. 152-165.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This <tei-title data-origname="title">affaire</tei-title>, which received significant media coverage in the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> and elsewhere, originated in an altercation in August 1833 between a white planter and a free man of color, ultimately resulting in an authoritarian mass mobilization against protesting men of color. A majority of the more than one hundred arrested received severe sentences — forced labor, deportations, executions — after a hasty trial conducted by local courts. In this issue, the article “A look at the colonial regime and its effects” is followed by an article entirely devoted to the "Grand'Anse Uprising,” which includes a list of the 117 accused.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Schloss, Rebecca Hartkopf. <tei-title data-origname="title">Sweet Liberty: The Final Days of Slavery in Martinique</tei-title> Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2011. 152-165.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n9F29" id="n9F29" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Trois jours d’insurrection parisienne en juillet 1830, les Trois Glorieuses, mettent fin au règne de Charles X et à la Restauration, régime supplanté par la Monarchie de Juillet avec à sa tête, Louis-Philippe, roi des Français.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Three days of insurrection across Paris in July 1830, the so-called <tei-title data-origname="title">Trois Glorieuses</tei-title>, put an end to the reign of Charles X and the Bourbon Restoration, installing, in its place, the July Monarchy of Louis-Philippe, who accepted the title “King of the French.”</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n3257" id="n3257" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">En proclamant, en son article 73, que les colonies seraient régies par « des lois et des règlements particuliers », la Charte constitutionnelle de 1814 cautionnait, de fait, d’importants abus à l’encontre de la population de couleur. L’élimination du mot « règlements » de l’article 64 (par ailleurs identique) de la nouvelle Charte de 1830 signalerait donc, comme l’explique la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue,</tei-title> une volonté de la part du nouveau gouvernement de remédier à la situation en rapprochant les colonies de la métropole. </tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Larcher, Silyane. <tei-title data-origname="title">L’autre citoyen: L’idéal républicain et les Antilles après l’esclavage</tei-title>, Paris. Armand Colin, 2014, p. 114-117.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Per Article 73 of the Constitutional Charter of 1814: “The colonies are governed by specific laws and regulations.” Article 64 of the revised Charter of 1830 is equivalent save for the removal of the word “regulations.” As the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> explains, the capacity of colonial governments to abide by their own particular “regulations” enabled significant forms of abuse and oppression of people of color. Thus the new charter would appear to reform these injustices by bringing the colonies more in line with the <tei-title data-origname="title">métropole</tei-title>.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Larcher, Silyane. <tei-title data-origname="title">L’autre citoyen: L’idéal républicain et les Antilles après l’esclavage</tei-title>, Paris. Armand Colin, 2014, 114-117.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n917D" id="n917D" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Les titres de noblesse, abolis au début de la Révolution, sont rétablis avec la Restauration de la monarchie en 1814 et maintenus pendant la monarchie de Juillet. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Titles of nobility were abolished at the start of the Revolution but reestablished with the Restoration of the Monarchy in 1814 and maintained during the July Monarchy. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n332A" id="n332A" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Les ordonnances locales qui régissent, de fait, les territoires coloniaux, tendent systématiquement à protéger les intérêts des planteurs blancs. Dès 1831, Mondésir Richard objecte auprès du gouvernement métropolitain : « La Charte nous promet des lois, et vous nous replacez inhumainement sous l’empire des ordonnances, et le mauvais vouloir des Colons. »</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Richard, Mondésir. <tei-title data-origname="title">Examen des deux projets de loi sur l'organisation des colonies : et sur les droits civils et politiques des hommes de couleur, </tei-title>Paris, Imprimerie Porthmann, 1831, p. 11.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Local ordinances which <tei-title data-origname="title">de facto</tei-title> govern colonial territories systematically tend to protect the interests of white planters. As early as 1831, Mondésir Richard decried the unjustness of this system to the French government: “The Charter promises us laws, and you inhumanly put us back under the empire of ordinances, and the ill will of the colonists.”</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Richard, Mondésir. <tei-title data-origname="title">Examen des deux projets de loi sur l'organisation des colonies: et sur les droits civils et politiques des hommes de couleur. </tei-title>Paris: Imprimerie Porthmann, 1831. 11.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n0490" id="n0490" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Les lois d’avril 1833, parfois connues sous le nom de <tei-title data-origname="title">Charte coloniale</tei-title>, devaient en principe confirmer l’égalité des populations libres des colonies. Elles ne font cependqnt qu’appuyer l’hégémonie des colons blancs en leur assurant la domination au sein d’assemblées locales et en maintenant des conditions de cens qui leur sont largement favorables.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">The laws passed in April 1833, referred to collectively as the <tei-title data-origname="title">Colonial Charter</tei-title>, were meant, in principle, to confirm the equality of the free populations of the colonies. In practice, however, they ensured white landowners’ control of local assemblies and set tax requirements for voting that barred all but a few men of color from the electoral process.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n8508" id="n8508" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">L’implication ici est que le statut des hommes libres de couleur par rapport aux propriétaires terriens blancs en 1834 est plus dégradé que le statut des gens ordinaires (membres du tiers état, l'ordre le plus bas de la hiérarchie sociale) par rapport au clergé ou à l'aristocratie au cours de la ancien régime, qui étaient au moins reconnus comme ayant des droits égaux à l'humanité.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">The implication here is that the status of free men of color relative to white landowners in 1834 is more degraded than the status of commoners (members of the third estate, the lowest order of the social hierarchy) relative to the clergy or aristocracy during the ancien regime, who were at least recognized as having equal claims to humanity. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n6759" id="n6759" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Un exemple de ce type de concession est l’ordonnance royale du 24 février 1831 permettant aux  « libres de couleur  » de Martinique d’hériter des blancs, d’exercer la médecine, la chirurgie ou la pharmacie, de s’établir en métropole, et d’accèder à l'éducation.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Schloss, Rebecca Hartkopf. <tei-title data-origname="title">Sweet Liberty: The Final Days of Slavery in Martinique</tei-title>. <tei-title data-origname="title">Philadelphia.</tei-title> University of Pennsylvania Press. 2011, p. 136.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">An example of this type of concession is the royal ordinance of February 24, 1831 allowing the free men of color of Martinique to inherit property from whites, to practice medicine, surgery or pharmacy, to settle in metropolitan France, and to receive education.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Schloss, Rebecca Hartkopf. <tei-title data-origname="title">Sweet Liberty: The Final Days of Slavery in Martinique. </tei-title>Philadelphia. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press. 2011. 136.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n684A" id="n684A" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Ce passage est révélateur du public visé par la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>et de l’objectif qu’elle se donne auprès de celui-ci. Le sensationnalisme qui a pu caractériser le traitement médiatique de l’<tei-title data-origname="title">affairede la Grand’Anse </tei-title>a sans doute éffarouché quelques lecteurs potentiellement favorables à la cause des personnes de couleur, la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>promet de remédier à cet état de fait en apportant un contrepoids nécessaire, en vue d’éclairer des lecteurs métropolitains bienveillants mais trop éloignés des réalités coloniales.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This meta-commentary on the state of colonial reporting is revelatory of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>’s intended audience. If sensationalist coverage of the <tei-title data-origname="title">affaire de la Grand’Anse </tei-title>might have instilled doubts in readers potentially sympathetic to the cause of expanded rights for free people of color, the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>promises to provide a necessary counterbalance, and thus to attract benevolent but otherwise disengaged metropolitan French readers to the emancipatory cause. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n9C9A" id="n9C9A" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="référence_culturelle" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Il s’agit d’une référence à <tei-title data-origname="title">Turcaret</tei-title>,une comédie populaire de 1709 par Alain-René Lesage, dont le personnage titulaire est un usurier et ancien laquais qui tente de s’insinuer dans l’aristocratie.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Dans le contexte de la comparaison aux anciens titres de noblesse, l’« aristocratie des Turcarets »</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">semble donc faire allusion au système de pairie introduit à la Restauration et calqué sur le système anglais, créant une catégorie de noblesse non héréditaire et transactionnelle.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="cultural_reference" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This is a reference to <tei-title data-origname="title">Turcaret</tei-title>, a popular comedy from 1709 by Alain-René Lesage, whose titular character is a usurer and former valet who attempts to insinuate himself into the aristocracy. The reference thus appears to be to the recently redefined system of peerage, modeled on the English system, which created a non-hereditary and thus acquirable and transactional category of nobility. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n5DA0" id="n5DA0" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="référence_culturelle" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Mésence, le tyran étrusque dans l'<tei-title data-origname="title">Énéide</tei-title> de Virgile, Caligula, l’empereur romain connu pour sa cruauté et sa débauche, et Louis XI, emblème du despotisme médiéval dans la littérature romantique, sont ici évoqués pour sous-entendre que la cruauté et la corruption des planteurs et administrateurs coloniaux surpassent celle des personnages historiques ou mythologiques les plus infâmes.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="cultural_reference" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Mésence, or Mezentius, the tyrant Etruscan king in Virgil’s <tei-title data-origname="title">Aeneid</tei-title>, Caligula, the Roman emperor notorious for cruelty and debauchery, and Louis XI, an emblem of dark-age despotism familiar to readers of nineteenth-century French literature, are here evoked with the implication that the cruelty and corruption of white colonial landowners and authorities surpasses that of the most infamous historical, or mythological figures.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n3E34" id="n3E34" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
